entry.et: Middle English, from Late Latin extension-, extensio, from Latin extendere

def.dt: :the action of extending :state of being extended
:an enlargement in scope or operation tools are extensions of human hands
:the total range over which something extends :compass
:the stretching of a fractured or dislocated limb so as to restore it to its natural position
:an unbending movement around a joint in a limb (as the knee or elbow) that increases the angle between the bones of the limb at the joint compare flexion 4a
:an increase in time allowed under agreement or concession
:a program that geographically extends the educational resources of an institution by special arrangements (as correspondence courses) to persons otherwise unable to take advantage of such resources
:a section or line segment forming an additional length
:an extra telephone connected to the principal line
:a length of natural or synthetic hair that is worn attached to one's natural hair
:a series of usually three or four characters following a dot at the end of the name of a computer file that specifies the file's format or purpose
:a mathematical set (as a field or group) that includes a given and similar set as a subset
:an electric cord fitted with a plug at one end and a receptacle at the other
